title: The Kansas City Chiefs Won—and Lost Patrick Mahomes
sub_head: The Kansas City Chiefs advanced to the AFC Championship but their superstar quarterback left with a concussion. History shows it may be difficult for him to return in time.
body:
The Kansas City Chiefs had a safe lead against the Cleveland Browns when the one thing that couldn’t happen to them did. They lost Patrick Mahomes.
Mahomes left with a concussion. The Chiefs nearly blew it. Then Chad Henne, Mahomes’s backup, pulled off a pair of improbable plays to seal a nutty 22-17 win and send Kansas City to the AFC Championship.
But before the Chiefs host the Buffalo Bills in that game for a spot in the Super Bowl, there’s one outstanding question: Will Mahomes be available to play?
The odds aren’t great. From 2015 to 2019, NFL quarterbacks were held out a median of seven days after suffering a concussion in a game, according to the league. The AFC Championship is exactly a week after Sunday’s game—meaning Mahomes would have to return earlier than normal to play.
It’s also not as simple as Mahomes saying he feels ready to play. It’s not in his hands. It’s not in the team’s hands, either.
